summary: A 2006 Palm Beach Post article discussing the legal case against Jeffrey Epstein, focusing on the legal principle that ignorance of a minor's age is not a valid defense in sex crime cases. It details the police investigation, the grand jury's indictment on a lesser charge, and includes commentary from legal experts and statements from alleged victims.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the article, accused of unlawful sex acts with minors at his Palm Beach home. He was indicted by a grand jury on a charge of felony solicitation of prostitution.

persons.name: Bob Dekle
persons.context: A legal expert quoted extensively on the legal standards for prosecuting sex crimes against minors, including the irrelevance of the defendant's knowledge of the victim's age.

persons.name: Eliot Spitzer
persons.role: New York Attorney General and gubernatorial candidate
persons.context: Reported to have returned about $50,000 in campaign contributions received from Jeffrey Epstein due to the Palm Beach scandal.

persons.name: Mark Green
persons.role: Candidate for New York Attorney General
persons.context: Reported to have returned $10,000 in campaign contributions to Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: Epstein's defense attorney who maintained Epstein passed a polygraph test and that the alleged victims' stories lacked credibility.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Hired by Epstein when he became aware of the investigation; provided prosecutors with information about alleged victims' discussions of drug and alcohol use.

persons.name: Betty Resch
persons.role: Former prosecutor, now in private practice
persons.context: Commented on the prosecutorial challenges when alleged victims return multiple times, potentially making them less sympathetic to a jury.

connections.description: Epstein was a financial patron/donor to Spitzer's political campaign, leading Spitzer to return contributions after the scandal broke.
Epstein was a donor to Green's political campaign, leading Green to return contributions.
Goldberger is identified as Epstein's defense attorney, making statements in his defense.
Dershowitz was hired by Epstein as his lawyer when he became aware of the investigation.

events.title: News Article Published on Epstein Case
events.description: The Palm Beach Post publishes an article detailing the legal case against Jeffrey Epstein, including expert legal analysis and victim statements.

events.title: Grand Jury Indicts Epstein
events.description: A Palm Beach County grand jury indicts Jeffrey Epstein on a single charge of felony solicitation of prostitution, following an 11-month police investigation.

events.title: Police Investigation into Epstein
events.description: An 11-month Palm Beach police investigation finds probable cause to charge Epstein with unlawful sex acts with a minor and lewd and lascivious molestation involving five underage girls.

events.title: Politicians Return Epstein Contributions
events.description: New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer and candidate Mark Green return campaign contributions ($50,000 and $10,000 respectively) received from Jeffrey Epstein.

keyFacts: Legal experts state that ignorance of a minor's age is not a valid defense against charges of sexual activity with a minor.
Despite an 11-month police investigation finding probable cause for serious charges, a grand jury indicted Epstein only on the lesser charge of felony solicitation of prostitution.
At least one alleged victim told police Epstein knew she was underage (16), and another (14 at the time) said he threatened her to keep quiet.

Epstein's defense claimed he passed a polygraph test showing he didn't know the girls were minors, and his attorney Alan Dershowitz provided prosecutors with information about alleged victims' drug/alcohol use.
The article highlights the prosecutorial challenges in child sex abuse cases, especially when victims return multiple times or have credibility issues, and when the defendant is wealthy.
